habitat_description:
This species is found in California and Oregon. Found in woodland, brushland, forests, and grassland-woodland areas that are close to water bodies, such as ponds, lakes, streams and drainages (Stebbins 2003). It occurs in elevations ranging from sea level to 1920 m (Stebbins 2003).

The distribution range of this species extends from southwestern Oregon into western California, at elevations from sea level to approximately 1920 meters (Brown et al. 1995; Nussbaum et al. 1983; Rossman et al. 1996; Stebbins 2003). Primarily considered a semiaquatic snake, riparian zones represent corridors of dispersal into more terrestrial conditions. This species is known to burrow in or using soil, leaf litter, and fallen logs.  Individuals are often observed basking on boulders and along banks of water bodies. IT hides under water, under rocks, and among exposed roots of trees (Natureserve.org). Habitats include creeks, low to moderate gradient medium sized rivers, and shallow water pools, rocky fast –flowing streams, soft bottoms, and woodland-grass ecotones. Riparian habitats are described as herbaceous wetland and moist woodlands (Ernst and Ernst 2003; Nussbaum et al. 1983; Rossman et al. 1996; Stebbins 2003).

SW	-Cover is provided by the dense vegetation characteristic of riparian zones such as herbaceous wetlands.
